Posts.Content: Bliz wrote: I thought I posted this in the morning, but later couldnt find it. So if it is floating out around here somewhere and I missed it, please forgive. I am still trying to address the fairly horrible menopausal issues I had before being diagnosed BC. Has anyone used bioidentical hormones for menopause symptoms and know if they are also out, once diagnosed? My cancer was hormone positive and Stage 1/Grade 1, no node involvement. Dx 6/13/2007, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Bioidentical Hormones/Are they out too? Bliz Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2007 11:46AM Bliz wrote: There was bad news in the MRI so I was busy adjusting to that and didnt call the therapist. Now the lupectomy is tomorrow, so hopefully after I feel better from that. I jsut hate not being myself, the upbeat, active, healthy me. I want her back!!!
Posts.Title: Depressed Bliz Bliz

Posts.Content: Bliz wrote: As the lumpectomy and treatment approach, I am getting really down. I am not a down person, but this has shook me to my foundation. I did so many things right as for as my health. I never in my wildest dreams thought I would have breast cancer at 55. I know, I must be dreaming. I guess a lot of my self esteem came from being healthy and fit. I also know I am throwing a huge pity party for myself right now, beause so many others have it so much worse. Still all of this does not help me get out of my funk. I guess I am just going through a lot of emotions. Right now it is sadness and anger and depression rolled into one. In general I have had a lot of minor and now this major health issue in the last two years. I feel like I have aged over night. ANd in some sick way, part of the downer is even though I have BC, it is not what is causing the rest of my malaise. Having had tons of tests and tried every menopause treatment there is, I will still have to try to figure out what that is all about after the BC treatment is over. Sorry to whine and cry so much, but I am used to feeling very good physically, mentally, emotionally and all that is really down the tubes right now. Dx 6/13/2007, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Depressed Bliz Bliz

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2007 02:56AM Bliz wrote: Thanks everyone. I will take some pro-active steps today, including calling the surgeon and my old therapist. Thanks for all the upbeat thoughts and ideas. You have all been so helpful. I can not emphasize enough how this is not the usual me, even in adversity. I hope it changes real soon.
Posts.Title: Depressed Bliz Bliz

Posts.Content: Bliz wrote: Harley, I decided to start a new thread on this, as it now looks like we both have a lot of questions related to all ths. Below is the email from my doc regarding my path report and her recommendations. I didnt even think I was in the category of needing chemo. Previously have been told radiation and possibly endocrine therapy. I have a lot of questions for her so starting to formulate. I will also look at the adjuvant site with the recommendations that were given here. I was told by radiologist there was one tumor about 8mm and two satelites about .5 each. So maybe she is wrapping that all together to get the .9 Not sure. that is one of my questions. Open for all discussion and help here. I am 55, otherwise extremely healthy and the cancer was found on a routine mammogram. ******** You have a great path report: lymph nodes negative, margins free. your tumor is about 9millimeters in size (plus the additional tissue taken out with the original biopsy). you fit the characteristics of someone who might benefit from an additional test called oncotype dx, which gives a recurrence score and helps us identify if your tumor has a low, intermediate, or high risk for recurrence. this may affect the type of treatment recommendations offered to you by the oncologist. with your permission, I'd like to send the tissue off for testing, and your insurance will be billed. there is a study offered at the university in which women who fall into the intermediate category are randomized to receive either chemotherapy followed by endocrine treatment versus just endocrine treatment without chemo. it's hard to know right now what is the most beneficial course of treatment for those patients whose tumors fall into the intermediate category. the benefit of the study is that the oncotype testing is paid for by the study if your insurance doesn't cover it. some women may have a hard time accepting the idea of being randomized into one of two treatment regimens, but the truth is that if 100 oncologists were polled regarding their recommendations for a woman who is your age, with all of your tumor/lymph node characteristics, exactly half would offer chemo and endocrine therapy, and half would offer just endocrine therapy! So, think about this, and if you agree, I'd like to have our study coordinator call you. ************** Dx 6/13/2007, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Bliz wrote: I am going tomorrow to a breast specialist connected to the local medical school. So far I went to the general surgeon associated with the local breast center at the hospital closest to me. Pending other tests the diagnosis is invasive ductile carcinoma Stage and Grade 1. I assume the actual diagnosis wouldnt change much but the treatment might. Not really sure. Are there reasons I should go to the specialist? I am not even sure what to ask her except if she would have a different treatment opinion. Maybe something less invasive. Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 06:54PM Bliz wrote: Massage has been so important to my overall health, it would be difficult to give up.  They even offered free massage through the BC center in my area. I would think it would be beneficial to the overall health of any BC survivor as long as there were not contraindications with the LE area. I would say to consult an LE massag expert and/or avoid the affected area.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2008 07:08PM Bliz wrote: Thanks, Binney, for all the help and suggestions.  I am away from my docs for a few more weeks but will see all of them when I get back.  I talked to a MT tonight that does lymph work.  She showed me some light touch, short stroke massage to do under the arm until I get back.  Other than that I will take it easy with the yard work and and check out your links. The swelling seems to be in the effected breast only and does go away. Stage1/Grade1/0 of 3 nodes/Er+/Her-/.9mm/lupect/5 day rads/IDC
